§ 12-101 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CEMETERY. A burial park for earth interments, or tomb interments.
   COLUMBARIUM. An above ground vault with niches for placement and perpetual
storage of funeral urns.
   COLUMBARIUM INTERMENT. The permanent placement of a funeral urn containing
the cremated remains of a person, in a columbarium niche.
   INTERMENT. The permanent disposition of the remains of a deceased person by
burial, by cremation, interment and burial, or by entombment.
   LOT. Numbered tracts within the cemetery as shown on the record plat,
consisting of one or more spaces and grouped into a cemetery section.
   LOT MARKER. A concrete post used by the cemetery to locate the corner of a
lot.
   MONUMENT. A tombstone or memorial of granite or marble.
   OPENING/CLOSING. Removal of earth for an interment and replacing of earth
over the burial vault or urn, as specified in this article.
   SECTION. The primary subdivision of the cemetery, composed of a collection
of numbered lots.
   SPACE. An area for one interment (usually four feet by 11 feet) grouped with
other spaces to form a cemetery lot.
(Ord. 1113, passed 4-21-1992; Ord. 1593, passed 7-3-2012)
§ 12-102 CEMETERY; NAME.
   The City Cemetery heretofore established shall be known as the “Wamego City
Cemetery”.
(Ord. 1113, passed 4-21-1992)
§ 12-103 SAME; SURVEY, PLAT OF.
   The survey and plat of the Cemetery into lots, blocks, parking, roadways and
walks, as recorded in the Office of the Register of Deeds of Pottawatomie
County, shall be the official survey and plat of the cemetery.
(Ord. 1113, passed 4-21-1992)
§ 12-104 CITY CLERK’S RESPONSIBILITIES.
   (a)   The City Clerk shall be responsible for maintaining official records
of conveyances, owners and interments in the Wamego City Cemetery.
   (b)   He or she shall collect and account for cemetery funds from the sale
of lots, permanent maintenance charges or other charges, and shall issue all
cemetery deeds, permits and licenses as authorized by this article.
(Ord. 1113, passed 4-21-1992)
§ 12-105 CEMETERY SUPERINTENDENT’S RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The duties of the Cemetery Superintendent shall be assigned to an employee
or employees of the city by the City Manager. He or she shall be responsible
for maintaining the cemetery, including fencing, gates, grounds, streets,
buildings and all other parts thereof, in good condition, and shall take such
means as may be necessary to protect the cemetery from damage and depreciation
of any kind. He or she shall cause all persons within the cemetery to observe
the rules and regulations pertaining to conduct therein and the care and
adornment of cemetery lots. He or she shall mark all graves for opening/closing
and shall secure persons to perform the opening/closing. Her or she shall also
mark out locations for monuments and inspect all new monument installations to
ensure compliance with city specifications.
(Ord. 1113, passed 4-21-1992)
§ 12-106 SAME; LOTS; SALE; CONDITION.
   Regulations relating to lots in the cemetery and the sale of the lots shall
be as follows:
   (a)   The charge for sale of all spaces in the city cemetery shall be
determined by resolution adopted by the governing body;
   (b)   All unsold lots or fractions of lots, surveyed and platted for grave
spaces in the cemetery, shall be sold by lots, fractions thereof or single
grave spaces by the city for such sum or sums as the governing body shall
prescribe by resolution;
   (c)   All lots and grave spaces shall be used solely for the purpose of
interment of human bodies;
   (d)   No lot or grave space shall be used for the purpose of burial, nor a
deed issued until the purchase price therefor shall have been paid in full to
the city (or until the City Clerk shall have satisfactory guarantee of such
payment);
   (e)   Upon the full payment of the purchase price for any lot, fraction
thereof or grave space owned by the city, plus full payment of the cost for
permanent maintenance thereof, a cemetery certificate shall be issued by the
City Clerk which shall be signed by the Mayor and attested by the City Clerk
under the seal of the city;
   (f)   One half of the monies received from the sale of lots, fractions
thereof and grave spaces shall be deposited by the City Clerk into the General
Operating Fund, and one half of said monies shall be deposited to the Cemetery
Reserve Fund for use only in the purchase and development of new cemetery land.
All permanent maintenance funds received must be used in accordance with the
provisions of § 12-125; and
   (g)   Babyland. Lots 1, 8 and 9 of section 7 of the city cemetery shall be
reserved for interment of infants 18 months and younger. Owners of Babyland
grave spaces are subject to the regulations found elsewhere in this article,
unless exceptions are specified.
(Ord. 1113, passed 4-21-1992)
§ 12-107 TRANSFER OF LOTS.
   No sale, transfer or conveyance of any lot, fraction thereof or grave space
shall be made by the owner thereof until first approved by the City Manager.
The City Manager may authorize the purchase by the city of any unused or unsold
lot or fraction thereof from the legal title holder at no more than the current
price. No space, lot or portion thereof may be transferred if containing a
monument or part of a monument or if explicit or implied reference is made to
it by the monument. The charge for transfer of deeds shall be as established
under §
12-112.
(Ord. 1113, passed 4-21-1992)
§ 12-108 INTERMENTS.
   Regulations relating to interment requirements for the city cemetery are as
follows.
   (a)   Only one interment shall be made in any standard grave space, with the
following exceptions:
      (1)   A mother and infant or infants interred in the same casket;
      (2)   Two infants interred in the same casket; and
      (3)   Two cremains interments in the same adult grave space.
   (b)   In designated cremains spaces only one internment shall be permitted
on a space.
   (c)   A non-sealed two piece concrete box is the minimum requirement for
containing a casket, for all interments in the city cemetery except cremains
interments.
   (d)   No interment shall be made for other than a relative or heir of any
lot owner without the written permission of the lot owner, filed with the City
Clerk, and no lot owners shall allow interments to be made in their lots for
remuneration.
(Ord. 1113, passed 4-21-1992)
§ 12-109 GRAVE OPENING; FUNERALS.
   (a)   No grave shall be opened in the city cemetery by anyone other than
City of Wamego employees or contract workers.
   (b)   Standard graves shall be excavated to a depth of at least five feet,
except that the excavation required for an infant interment shall be not less
than three and one-half feet. No part of the container or vault shall be closer
to the ground surface than 30 inches.
   (c)   Cremains graves shall be excavated to a depth of three feet, six
inches to four feet and shall have a width of at least one foot. Encasement of
cremains in poured concrete shall be required for all non-permanent containers
which are not contained in a vault. Three inches poured concrete shall be
allowed under the container and concrete shall not be closer then one foot from
the surface.
   (d)   Funeral processions must be in the city cemetery by 11:00 a.m. on
weekends and holidays.
(Ord. 1113, passed 4-21-1992)
§ 12-110 SAME; NOTIFICATION.
   (a)   Before any grave shall be excavated, written application shall be made
to the City Clerk or Cemetery Superintendent requesting such work to be done.
   (b)   Such application shall be made not less than 16 working hours before
the time of interment, except as required under §
12-111. The application requesting a grave to be opened or dug may be made by:
      (1)   The owner of the lot or his or her duly authorized agent;
      (2)   The Funeral Director or person in charge of interment; or
      (3)   Some other authorized person.
(Ord. 1113, passed 4-21-1992)
§ 12-111 SAME; IMMEDIATE INTERMENT.
   (a)   If an immediate interment (within 24 hours of death) is required the
application for grave opening shall be made as specified under §
12-110 except that such application shall be made not less than four working
hours before the time of interment.
   (b)   Charges for immediate interment opening and closing shall be as set
out under §
12-112.
(Ord. 1113, passed 4-21-1992)
§ 12-112 OPENING, CLOSING, OTHER CHARGES AND FEES.
   (a)   The governing body shall fix by resolution the charges for opening and
closing of graves or for inurnments in the cemetery, and shall also establish
charges and fees for other services associated with the cemetery. All such
charges and fees shall be paid in full to the City Clerk, who shall issue a
general receipt for all monies received. All monies shall be deposited to the
General Operating Fund of the City Treasury, for use in maintenance of the city
cemetery. Full payment for an opening, closing must be received before work is
commenced.
   (b)   Expenses associated with indigent interments shall be reimbursed to
the city as per current State of Kansas Social Rehabilitation Services
policies. Full payment for indigent interment must be received before opening/
closing is commenced.
(Ord. 1113, passed 4-21-1992)
§ 12-113 REOPENING OF GRAVES; DISINTERMENT.
   (a)   Any person desiring to reopen any grave in the cemetery to disinter or
remove any body therefrom, or for any other purpose shall make written
application to the City Clerk or Cemetery Superintendent requesting such work
to be done. A charge for said service shall be set at twice the amount charged
for opening and closing graves as set out in §
12-112, except that, if it is determined that the disinterment will correct an
error of the city, no charge shall be required.
   (b)   The following rules shall apply.
      (1)   Reopening of a grave and removal of a body shall be under the
supervision of the Cemetery Superintendent.
      (2)   All markers designating the interment shall be removed at the time
of disinterment.
(Ord. 1113, passed 4-21-1992)
§ 12-114 MONUMENTS, MARKERS.
   Requirements for placing monuments or markers are given below.
   (a)   All grave spaces must be marked with a temporary marker by the funeral
home immediately after interment, if a monument does not exist.
   (b)   A permanent marker is required within one year of interment.
   (c)   Monuments in the cemetery must be made of granite, marble or bronze,
except that the Cemetery Superintendent may give written permission to install
monuments of other durable materials. Markers shall be made of permanent
materials (except temporary markers may be placed until such time as their
appearance warrants removal).
   (d)   Lot owners may mark boundaries in cement or stone, however, original
markers must not be disturbed and flush mounting is required.
   (e)   Government markers may be installed by city employees or contract
workers. The charge shall be as established under §
12-112.
   (f)   Monuments and markers shall be installed in accordance with
specifications approved by the governing body and on file in the office of the
City Clerk. Said specifications shall include provisions for monuments in
Babyland.
   (g)   Maintenance of monuments, foot stones and private markers is the
responsibility of the lot owner.
(Ord. 1113, passed 4-21-1992)
§ 12-115 FOOT STONES.
   All foot stones shall be installed flush with the ground level except for
those lots where existing foot stones have been installed above ground.
(Ord. 1113, passed 4-21-1992)
§ 12-116 MONUMENT WORK; PERMIT; FEE.
   (a)   All monument and marker installations in the city cemetery shall be
performed by professional monument installers. Before working in the city
cemetery, installers must submit to the City Clerk proof of public liability
insurance in the amount of $50,000, and pay a permit fee as provided under §
12-112.
   (b)   The Cemetery Superintendent shall mark out the location for monuments
or markers.
   (c)   If, upon inspection by the Cemetery Superintendent, a monument or
marker is determined to be improperly installed, the city reserves the right to
require the installer to correct the deficiency.
(Ord. 1113, passed 4-21-1992)
§ 12-117 ENCLOSING LOTS, COVERING GRAVES PROHIBITED.
   Any fence, hedge, coping, curbing, or other means of enclosure of a lot is
prohibited. Any covering for a lot or grave except sod is prohibited.
(Ord. 1113, passed 4-21-1992)
§ 12-118 PERMANENT MOUNDING OF GRAVES PROHIBITED.
   The permanent mounding up of a grave is prohibited.
(Ord. 1113, passed 4-21-1992)
§ 12-119 PERMANENT PLANTINGS.
   (a)   Permission to plant. Prior to planting, the Cemetery Supervisor shall
approve all permanent plant materials and shall approve planting locations,
which must be within eight inches of the headstone. In no event shall planting
be permitted adjacent to foot stones.
   (b)   Care. Cemetery personnel shall trim, prune and otherwise care for
plant materials, as provided under §
12-126. Neglected, misplaced, dead, unkempt, unauthorized or hazardous
plantings, including trees, may be removed by the Cemetery Supervisor or crew
as necessary to maintain the attractive, safe and neat appearance of the
cemetery.
(Ord. 1113, passed 4-21-1992; Ord. 1514, passed 11-6-2007)
§ 12-120 FLOWERS; OBJECTS.
   (a)   Artificial flowers not in a pre-approved permanent floral display
container of a type specified in the Wamego City Cemetery Regulations may be
placed adjacent to grave monuments only during the period from October 1
through April 1.
   (b)   (a)   Artificial flowers in a permanent floral display container of a
type specified in the Wamego City Cemetery Regulatons are permitted adjacent to
grave monuments year-round unless they become faded, broken or deteriorated.
      (b)   The Cemetery Supervisor or crew is authorized to remove and dispose
of these items, without notice to the lot owner.
   (c)   (a)   Seasonal flowers, cut flowers, artificial plants or flowers and
wreaths shall be permitted on the entire grave space area for ten days
immediately following the date of interment on said grave. They may also be
permitted on the entire grave space for a period commencing five days before
Memorial Day and ending five days following Memorial Day.
      (b)   Flowers not in a container of a type specified in the Wamego City
Cemetery Regulations shall be removed by the Cemetery Supervisor or crew, June
20 or thereafter.
   (d)   Damaged or faded artificial flowers or wreaths may be removed by the
Cemetery Supervisor as necessary to maintain the attractive, safe and neat
appearance of the cemetery. Any flowers on the ground will be discarded during
mowing season (June 20 through October 1).
   (e)   (a)   Lot owners are prohibited from placing on graves all toys,
glass, chinaware or other commemorative articles of any kind, with the
exception that memorial markers from the armed services or nationally
recognized clubs shall be permitted.
      (b)   Prohibited articles so placed shall be removed and disposed of by
the Cemetery Supervisor or crew, without notice to the owner.
(Ord. 1113, passed 4-21-1992; Ord. 1514, passed 11-6-2007)
§ 12-121 REMOVAL OF ENCLOSURES OR OTHER MATERIALS.
    The city reserves the right to remove any enclosure which has fallen into a
state of disrepair or any other material which is deemed detrimental to the
general good appearance of the grounds, or which shall, in the opinion of the
Cemetery Superintendent prevent the easy or proper care of the cemetery.
(Ord. 1113, passed 4-21-1992)
§ 12-122 CONDUCT IN THE CITY CEMETERY.
   (a)   All persons within the city cemetery shall conduct themselves in a
manner consistent with the solemn nature of a public cemetery.
   (b)   No persons, without specific authority from the city shall:
      (1)   Deposit rubbish or debris on any part of the cemetery grounds,
except in receptacles provided;
      (2)   Remove objects not belonging to them, pick flowers, shrubs or
plants or injure anything on any part of the grounds;
      (3)   Permit any dog to enter or remain in the cemetery;
      (4)   Consume or carry any type of liquid or alcoholic refreshments; and
      (5)   Carry firearms, except as permitted for military funerals.
(Ord. 1113, passed 4-21-1992)
§ 12-123 PERMANENT MAINTENANCE FUND; ESTABLISHED.
   There is hereby established a Permanent Maintenance Fund as authorized by
K.S.A. 12-1408 to 12-1411 and any amendments thereto.
(Ord. 1113, passed 4-21-1992)
§ 12-124 SAME; CHARGES; DEPOSIT.
   The permanent maintenance charge for each lot, fraction thereof, or grave
space sold shall be determined by resolution adopted by the governing body.
(Ord. 1113, passed 4-21-1992)
§ 12-125 SAME; USE; INVESTMENT.
   All monies received from these charges shall be deposited to the credit of
the Permanent Maintenance Fund in a checking account in a local bank. Funds may
be withdrawn only by a check signed by the City Manager and countersigned by
the City Clerk. All monies in the Permanent Maintenance Fund may be invested in
bonds of the United States or the State of Kansas, or any municipality thereof.
The interest received from such investments shall be deposited to the credit of
the General Fund and shall be used only for the maintenance and operation of
the cemetery.
(Ord. 1113, passed 4-21-1992)
§ 12-126 PERMANENT MAINTENANCE CARE; DEFINITION.
   Permanent maintenance care entitles a lot, fraction thereof or grave space
to normal maintenance including cutting of grass weeds, trimming of bushes and
trees, and removal of rubbish and trash. Such care does not include special
care or cultivation of flowers, bushes, shrubs or plants on lots, fractions
thereof or grave spaces. Repair of shifting or damaged monuments is the lot
owner’s responsibility unless damaged by city personnel.
(Ord. 1113, passed 4-21-1992)
§ 12-127 CEMETERY HOURS.
   The city cemetery shall be open to the public each day from 7:00 a.m. until
sundown. It shall be unlawful for any other person, other than cemetery
personnel or persons so authorized by the City Manager, to be upon the cemetery
grounds at any other time.
(Ord. 1113, passed 4-21-1992)
§ 12-128 COLUMBARIUM REGULATIONS.
   Regulations governing columbarium niche purchases and fees, columbarium
interment, marking and decoration shall be as contained in the Wamego City
Cemetery Columbarium Rules and Regulations to be approved and amended by
resolution of the city’s governing body, and made available to the public at
the office of the City Clerk.
(Ord. 1593, passed 7-3-2012)
ARTICLE 2: HOSPITAL
Section
   
12-201   Board of Trustees; appointment
   
12-202   Same; qualifications
   
12-203   Same; appointment; five-year term
   
12-204   Same; organization; oath; bond
   
12-205   Same; compensation
   
12-206   Same; bylaws, rules, regulations
   
12-207   Vouchers and warrants
   
12-208   Superintendent, assistants; appointment
   
12-209   Meetings, records, reports
   
12-210   Trustees, removal from office
   
12-211   Vacancies
   
12-212   Hospital admission
   
12-213   Hospital rules: application
   
12-214   Donations
   
12-215   Authority to invest donations, gifts, bequests, devises
§ 12-201 BOARD OF TRUSTEES; APPOINTMENT.
   (a)   The management and governance of the Wamego City Hospital shall be
lodged in a Board of Trustees, consisting of seven suitable persons chosen with
reference to their special fitness of such office. Except for the Trustees
serving at the adoption of this ordinance who shall continue to serve, unless
duly reappointed, until the end of their currently appointed terms without
further action required by the governing body, each Trustee shall be appointed
by the Mayor with the consent of the governing body and shall be known as and
constitute the Board of Trustees of the Wamego City Hospital.
   (b)   The Board of Trustees shall consist of positions numbered 1 through 7,
inclusive. The members of the Board of Trustees, as it is constituted at the
time of the adoption of this ordinance, shall be deemed to occupy positions
numbered 1 through 5, inclusive, ordered with position numbered 1 assigned to
the Board of Trustee member whose current term will be the first to expire
following the adoption of this ordinance and position numbered 5 assigned to
the Board of Trustee member whose current term will be the last to expire
following the adoption of this ordinance with positions numbered 2, 3 and 4
assigned in like fashion to the other Board of Trustee members in similar
order.
   (c)   Upon adoption and publication of this ordinance, the Mayor shall
appoint, in accord with this section, a qualified person to Position Number 6
and Position Number 7. The initial term for Board of Trustee Position Number 6
shall be until December 31, 2000. The initial term of Board of Trustee Position
Number 7 shall be until December 31, 2002.
(Ord. 1280, passed 2-17-1998)
§ 12-202 SAME; QUALIFICATIONS.
   Residents of the City of Wamego, Kansas, and the community about the city
may serve, upon appointment, qualification and upon taking any required oath
and the giving of any required bond, as members of the Board of Trustees. No
more than one physician, surgeon or pharmacist shall be eligible to serve upon
the Board of Trustees at anytime. No more than two persons who are not
residents of the City of Wamego, Kansas, may serve as a member of the Board of
Trustees at anytime. Any vacancy shall be filled in the same manner as the
making of the original appointment.
(Ord. 1280, passed 2-17-1998)
§ 12-203 SAME; APPOINTMENT; FIVE-YEAR TERM.
   At the first regular meeting of the governing body of the city, in January
of each year, the Mayor shall appoint one person for each position on the Board
of Trustees for which the term of such position expired during the preceding
calendar year.
(Ord. 1280, passed 2-17-1998)
§ 12-204 SAME; ORGANIZATION; OATH; BOND.
   Each Trustee shall within ten days after his or her appointment qualify by
taking the oath of civil officers. The Board shall at its first regular meeting
in January of each year, organize by the election of one of its members as
Chairperson, one or more of its members as a Vice Chairperson, one as Secretary
and one as Treasurer. No bond shall be required by any member except the
Treasurer, who before entering upon his or her duties shall give a good and
sufficient corporate surety bond, to be executed by a responsible bonding
company authorized to do business in Kansas, the bond to be approved by the
governing Board of the city in the sum of $10,000. Such bond shall be filed in
the office of the City Clerk. The cost of the surety bond shall be paid for
from the funds of the Wamego City Hospital. (K.S.A. 14-605)
§ 12-205 SAME; COMPENSATION.
   The Trustees shall receive no compensation for their service, except for the
Treasurer and Secretary who shall receive such compensation for their services
as may be deemed fair and proper by the Board of Trustees. Each Trustee may be
reimbursed for any necessary cash expenditures actually made for personal
expenses incurred as such Trustee if an itemized and verified statement of all
such expenses and money paid out shall be made and filed with the Secretary,
and allowed by the affirmative vote of a majority of the Board.
§ 12-206 SAME; BYLAWS, RULES, REGULATIONS.
   The Board of Trustees shall have the power to do all and everything
necessary to properly conduct the hospital in accord with these ordinances and
not inconsistent with the laws of the state and of the city. The Board of
Trustees shall make and adopt such bylaws, rules and regulations for its own
guidance and for the governance and management of the hospital, as it may deem
expedient and required for the economical and proper conduct of the hospital,
not inconsistent with the laws of the state and of the city.
(Ord. 1280, passed 2-17-1998)
§ 12-207 VOUCHERS AND WARRANTS.
   The Board shall have control of the expenditures of all money collected and
placed to the credit of the General Hospital Fund, and of the supervision, care
and custody of the grounds, buildings and facilities. All monies received for
the hospital shall be deposited with the Treasurer of the Board of Trustees,
and shall be paid out only upon warrants or checks drawn and signed by one of
the following: administrator of the hospital; business manager of the hospital;
or a member of the Board upon proper authenticated vouchers. At each regular
meeting of the Board, there shall be a review of a list of all warrants or
checks drawn for the period since the last regular meeting.
(Ord. 1013, passed 6-2-1987)
§ 12-208 SUPERINTENDENT, ASSISTANTS; APPOINTMENT.
   The Board of Trustees shall have the power to appoint or remove a suitable
Superintendent and any necessary assistants, and fix their compensation.
(Ord. 1280, passed 2-17-1998)
§ 12-209 MEETINGS, RECORDS, REPORTS.
   The Board shall hold meetings at least once each month and shall keep a
complete record of its proceedings; one of the Board shall visit and examine
the hospital at least twice each month and the Board shall submit to the
governing body of the city at its first regular meeting in January of each year
a detailed report of the proceedings of the Board and a statement of all
receipts and expenditures and money received during the year.
§ 12-210 TRUSTEES, REMOVAL FROM OFFICE.
   For good cause shown any member of the Board may be removed by the Mayor, by
and with the consent of the governing body. Before any member shall be removed,
charges in writing duly verified by oath shall be filed with the Clerk of the
city and due notice thereof given to the member against whom such charges have
been lodged, and the governing body shall have power to hear and determine such
charges on sworn evidence and their finding shall be final unless within ten
days from the date of the finding of the governing body, the member shall
appeal to the District Court of Pottawatomie County.
§ 12-211 VACANCIES.
   Vacancies in the Board occasioned by expiration of term of office, death,
removals, resignations or otherwise, shall be reported to the governing body
and be filled in like manner as original appointments. Such appointees, except
those appointed to fill vacancies resulting from the expiration of a term of
office shall hold office for the unexpired term of such member.
§ 12-212 HOSPITAL ADMISSION.
   The hospital shall be open to all inhabitants of the city and the community
about the city and for any person falling sick or being injured or maimed, and
every such person who is not a pauper shall pay a reasonable compensation for
occupancy, nursing, care, medicine or attendants, according to the rules and
regulations prescribed by the Board. The Board may exclude from the use of the
hospital any and all persons who shall willfully violate such rules and
regulations.
§ 12-213 HOSPITAL RULES: APPLICATION.
   The physicians, nurses, attendants and persons sick therein, all persons in
and around the hospital, all furniture and other articles used or brought
there, shall be subject to such rules and regulations as shall be prescribed by
the Board.
§ 12-214 DONATIONS.
   Any person or persons, firm, organization, corporation or society, desiring
to make donations of money, personal property or real estate, or to bequeath or
devise any property for the purpose of maintaining the Wamego City Hospital,
for the treatment of persons ill with bodily ailments and disease or for
surgery in general or special, or for special classes of diseases, whether
contagious or infectious or otherwise, shall have the right to vest the title
to the money or property so donated, bequeathed or devised in the Board of
Trustees of the Wamego City Hospital of Wamego, Kansas.
§ 12-215 AUTHORITY TO INVEST DONATIONS, GIFTS, BEQUESTS, DEVISES.
   All sums received from gifts, donations, bequests and devises in any one
year, except such sums as may be necessary for operating, repair and
maintenance expense for such current year, shall be placed in an endowment
fund, and shall be invested by the Board only in assets eligible for the
investment of funds of legal reserve life insurance companies in the State of
Kansas as stated in K.S.A. 40-403 and acts amendatory thereof or supplemental
thereto. The term “admitted assets” stated in such section shall be deemed to
mean the amount of the fund, and the provisions relating to limitation of
investments as a percent of surplus and loans to policyholders shall be
inapplicable with respect to the investment of the fund. However, it is
intended that nothing in this section shall prohibit the Board from using any
sums received from gifts, donations, bequests or devises, or any endowment
funds for the purpose of constructing, purchasing or acquiring any new hospital
buildings, additions, facilities or equipment, or the purchase or acquisition
of additional land needed for such construction of buildings, additions or
facilities. The use to be made of such donations, gifts, bequests or devises
shall not be in conflict with the terms and conditions of the donations, gifts,
bequests or devises.
ARTICLE 3: LIBRARY
Section
   
12-301   Public library established; Library Board
   
12-302   Library Board; membership; appointment
   
12-303   Same: officers; meetings
   
12-304   Same; powers and duties
   
12-305   Same; funds; disbursements; treasurer

12-307   Retaining library property
§ 12-301 PUBLIC LIBRARY ESTABLISHED; LIBRARY BOARD.
   The library of the city shall be known as “The Wamego Public Library”. The
Mayor with the approval of the governing body is hereby authorized to appoint a
Library Board for the operation and maintenance of such library as provided for
by K.S.A. 12-1218 through 12-1230 and all acts mandatory or supplemental
thereto; and the Board so appointed is authorized to continue the maintenance
of the library in accordance with provisions of the laws applicable thereto.
The Mayor shall be ex officio member of the Library Board with the same powers
as the appointed members but no person holding any office in the city shall be
appointed a member while holding such office.
§ 12-302 LIBRARY BOARD; MEMBERSHIP; APPOINTMENT.
   The Mayor shall appoint, with the approval of the governing body, a Library
Board for the city library. The Board shall consist of seven members to be
appointed in the manner and for terms provided by law and the Mayor of the city
who shall be ex officio a member of the Board with the same powers as appointed
members.
§ 12-303 SAME: OFFICERS; MEETINGS.
   (a)   The Board shall annually meet and organize by the election of a
Chairperson, a Secretary and a Treasurer and such other officers as they may
deem necessary. The Board shall fix the date and place of its regular meetings
and special meetings may be called by the Chairperson or upon written request
of a majority of the members in the manner provided by law.
   (b)   Any Board member who has three consecutive, unexcused absences from
Board meetings or who misses more than six meetings in a calendar year will be
considered inactive and informed in writing that a replacement to the Board
will be sought by the governing body.
(Ord. 1486, passed 9-5-2006)
§ 12-304 SAME; POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Board shall be responsible for the general operation and maintenance of
the library and shall make and adopt rules and regulations for the
administration thereof in accordance with applicable state law.
§ 12-305 SAME; FUNDS; DISBURSEMENTS; TREASURER.
   The funds received and set over to the Library Board by the city shall be
deposited in a separate fund in the city treasury and the Treasurer of the city
may be ex officio Treasurer of the Library Board. All funds of the Library
Board shall be disbursed upon claims properly itemized and certified as
required by law. Warrant checks shall be signed by the Chairperson of the
Library Board and the Secretary and countersigned by the Treasurer of the
Library Board.
(K.S.A. 12-1226)
§ 12-306 DESTROYING LIBRARY PROPERTY.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully injure or destroy any book,
map, chart or magazine or any property of like nature belonging to the library.
§ 12-307 RETAINING LIBRARY PROPERTY.
   It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to take from the library any
book, map, chart, magazine or other personal property except in conformity with
the rules, or for any person willfully to retain any such personal property,
having lawfully or unlawfully obtained possession of same, after having been
notified by the librarian to return the same.
ARTICLE 4: AIRPORT
Section
   
12-401   Wamego Airport Board; creation; appointment; terms; vacancies
   
12-402   Same; organization
   
12-403   Same; compensation
   
12-404   Same; powers
   
12-405   Same; financial accountability
   
12-406   Same; limitations
§ 12-401 WAMEGO AIRPORT BOARD; CREATION; APPOINTMENT; TERMS; VACANCIES.
   The management and operation of the Wamego Municipal Airport shall be lodged
in a Board consisting of five suitable persons from the citizens of the city
and citizens who live within a three-mile radius of the city. They shall be
appointed by the Mayor with the consent of the governing body and shall be
known as and constitute the Wamego Airport Board. The appointed members of the
Board shall serve for three years except that the Mayor with the consent of the
governing body shall initially appoint one Board member for a term expiring one
year after the date of appointment, two Board members for a term expiring two
years after the date of appointment; and three Board members for a term
expiring three years after the date of appointment. Thereafter upon the
expiration of the term of any Board member, the Mayor with the consent of the
governing body shall appoint one person to serve as a Board member in each
vacancy created for a term of three years. Any member of the Board may be
removed by the governing body for the same cause as any appointive officer.
(Ord. 883, passed - -)
§ 12-402 SAME; ORGANIZATION.
   The appointed board members shall annually elect among themselves the
following officers: Chairperson; Vice Chairperson; and Secretary-Treasurer; and
shall meet on a regularly scheduled basis not less than quarterly at a location
to be determined by the Board. The Board shall keep minutes of each of their
meetings to be signed by the Chairperson and Secretary-Treasurer.
(Ord. 883, passed - -)
§ 12-403 SAME; COMPENSATION.
   Members of the Board shall receive no compensation for their services.
(Ord. 883, passed - -)
§ 12-404 SAME; POWERS.
   The Board shall have the following powers and authority:
   (a)   To make long range plans for the operation and improvement of the
airport for presentation to the governing body;
   (b)   To have the power to rent and lease airport hangar structures on a
month to month basis;
   (c)   To spend such funds as are delegated to it by the governing body and
as are collected from rents for the maintenance, upkeep and improvement of the
airport; and
   (d)   To, with the approval of the governing body, make and adopt rules and
regulations for the administration of the airport.
(Ord. 883, passed - -)
§ 12-405 SAME; FINANCIAL ACCOUNTABILITY.
   The Board shall keep such books as are sufficient to undergo a yearly audit,
the cost of the yearly audit to be paid for by the Board. The Board shall
provide quarterly financial statements to the governing body.
(Ord. 883, passed - -)
§ 12-406 SAME; LIMITATIONS.
   The Board shall not have authority to levy taxes, make expenditure of funds
not appropriated to them specifically by the governing body, to convey real
estate or to lease real estate or personal property for any period longer than
month to month or to contract any form of debt or to do any other acts not
specifically set out under the terms of this article or any resolution made by
the governing body.
(Ord. 883, passed - -)
ARTICLE 5: CITY PARKS
Section
   
12-501   Parks and Recreation Department; created

§ 12-501 PARKS AND RECREATION DEPARTMENT; CREATED.
   For the purpose of providing for the operation, maintenance and improvement
of a park system and conducting a supervised recreation program, there is
hereby established in the city a Parks and Recreation Department to function
under the direction of the City Manager.
(Ord. 1367, passed 12-4-2001)
§ 12-502 PARKS AND RECREATION DEPARTMENT SUPERVISOR.
   The Parks and Recreation Department Supervisor, subject to the direction of
the City Manager, shall be in charge of the operation, maintenance and
improvement of the city park system and operation of the city recreation
program, including establishment of suitable rules and regulations for the
conduct of the program. The Parks and Recreation Department Supervisor shall
have assistants and employees as may be determined by the City Manager.
(Ord. 1367, passed 12-4-2001)
§ 12-503 PARKS AND RECREATION ADVISORY BOARD; DUTIES; MEMBERSHIP; TERMS.
   For the purpose of advising the governing body in matters pertaining to the
operation, maintenance and improvements of a city park system and conducting a
supervised recreation program, including recommendations regarding suitable
rules for the conduct of the program, there is hereby established a Recreation
Advisory Board pursuant to K.S.A. 12-1930. Such Board shall be appointed by the
governing body of the city. No more than two members thereof shall reside
outside the corporate limits of the city. Members shall serve upon such Board
for the term for which they were appointed by the governing body to the
Recreation Commission and upon the expiration of the term of any member,
appointment shall be made to fill such position for a term of four years.
(Ord. 1367, passed 12-4-2001; Ord. 1443, passed 12-7-2004)
§ 12-504 PRESERVATION OF NATURAL STATE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, except duly authorized city employees,
to take, injure, or disturb any live or dead tree, plant, shrub, or flower, or
otherwise interfere with the natural state of city parks.
§ 12-505 GENERAL REGULATIONS.
   The city may post such rules and regulations, as are approved by the
governing body, pertaining to the use of the city parks in a conspicuous place
in each city park. Violations of these posted rules shall constitute a
violation of this code.
§ 12-506 CITY LAWS EXTENDED TO PARK.
   The laws of the city shall extend to and cover all city parks.
§ 12-507 POLICE JURISDICTION OVER PARKS.
   The city shall have police regulations governing any public parks belonging
to the city and the Chief of Police and law enforcement officers of the city
shall have full power to enforce city laws governing city parks and shall
maintain order therein.
§ 12-508 CITY OF WAMEGO PARKS; IDENTIFICATION.
   The following shall be defined as City of Wamego Parks: Miller Park, Morton
Park, Riverside Park; Railroad Park; Pennyland Park; Wamego City Park; Ball
Park located on 4th Street; and Wamego Recreation Complex, located at U.S. 24
and Balderson Boulevard.
(Ord. 1534, passed 12-2-2008)
§ 12-509 SAME; POSTING OF SPECIAL RULES.
   A city designee may post signs and notices informing the public of the
regulations regarding the use of the City of Wamego parks and recreational
facilities therein. The city designee may establish rules and regulations for
participation in all Recreation Department sponsored activities and special
events.
(Ord. 1534, passed 12-2-2008)
§ 12-510 SAME; SPECIAL USE.
   A city designee may authorize special uses for City of Wamego Parks and
accompanying facilities. Tents, canopies, awnings and other temporary
structures are prohibited in City of Wamego Parks except in designated areas
and upon special written approval by the city.
(Ord. 1534, passed 12-2-2008)
§ 12-511 SAME; HOURS.
   All City of Wamego Parks shall be open to the public between the hours of 5:
00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. inclusive. A city designee may authorize use of such
parks outside of the times specified herein.
(Ord. 1534, passed 12-2-2008)
§ 12-512 SAME; PROHIBITED BEHAVIOR.
   Disruptive behavior, including but not limited to: drunkenness, playing of
loud music, use of vile, offensive, obscene, or abusive language or gestures,
or engaging in noisy conduct that might cause alarm or anger to other park
visitors is hereby prohibited in City of Wamego Parks. Any person engaging in
such behavior shall be in violation of this article, and shall be subject to a
fine not to exceed $100.
(Ord. 1534, passed 12-2-2008)
§ 12-513 DANGEROUS WEAPONS NOT ALLOWED.
   (a)   Except as provided in division (b) below, it shall be unlawful for any
person to carry or have in his or her possession any firearm or dangerous
weapon or to shoot or discharge the same within the limits of any city parks.
   (b)   The provisions of division (a) above shall not apply to duly
authorized law enforcement officers in the performance of official duty.
§ 12-514 VEHICLE REGULATIONS.
   (a)   Motor vehicles, including any vehicle licensed to operate on public
streets, roads and highways and motorbikes, special purpose vehicles, go-carts
snowmobiles, off-road vehicles shall be always operated in a safe manner on
park roadways.
   (b)   Except as provided in division (c) below, it shall be unlawful for any
person to drive any motor driven vehicle over or across any portion of the city
parks or public grounds where decorative vegetation or grass exists except on
designated drives and parking areas.
   (c)   It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle in any park area unless it
is being driven by city staff for maintenance or emergency purposes or as part
of the set up or maintenance of a City Commission-approved or sponsored event.
(Ord. 1806, passed 10-15-2024)
§ 12-515 HUNTING.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to pursue, catch, trap, maim, kill,
shoot or take any wildlife, either bird or animal, in any manner at any time
while in any city park.
§ 12-516 FIRES.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to build or kindle any fire in any city
park except in the ovens, stoves or grills provided for that purpose by the
city, and such fire must be extinguished by the person, persons or parties
starting such fire, immediately after use thereof.
§ 12-517 CAMPING PROHIBITED.
   Overnight camping is hereby prohibited in city parks except where posted.
§ 12-518 PROHIBITION AGAINST ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES AND CEREAL MALT BEVERAGES.
   It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to use, consume or have on
the premises of any park or other city property within the city any alcoholic
liquor or cereal malt beverage.
§ 12-519 FIREWORKS.
   No fireworks shall be discharged or fired in any public park, except that
the governing body may issue special permits for fireworks displays on special
occasions to civic or patriotic organizations or to public school officials,
upon written application, only if the applicant agrees that such display shall
be open to the public and subject to the supervision and direction of the Fire
Chief.
(Ord. 1523, passed 6-17-2008)
